comments.commentBody: Danny Hakim God Bless you! Than you and the NYT for starting to show us all the tax payes the real thing. I hope you and you continue to turn stones around these billonaires system of services for the frail, disabled, and elderly.It is a real shamee!- There all still many, many programs for the disabled earning millons around NYC and NYS that do a great job, just in the outside, for a show. I have learned now that working for these programs pays, you can make a real good money without receiving appropriate oversight,appropriate trainings, without practicing appropriately employement standars. Paying more than a million dollars for every person??- This is a shame.

I think all advocacy organizations should issue a statement in response to this article. We should also discuss ways that we can help empower such victims and their families - perhaps by facilitating the organization of a parent cooperative where public funding follows the person with disabilities and where the parent cooperative oversees the living conditions and directs the funding. At the minimum, such a cooperative could serve as ombuds and help pierce the decades-old and still pervasive wall of silence and thwart the customary shifting of inappropriate employees. We must not remain silent while such inappropriate policies that help cover up such shameful behavior continue to victimize those whom we purportedly serve. Silence equals death.

Executive Direcetor
CLEAR: Center for Legal Education and Advocacy Resources, Inc.
http://www.CLEARidea.org
(315) 691-3000

Van55@39: I have it on good authority (my wife) that Spuyten Duyvil originally meant "spit of the Devil" in old Dutch.

SueJean@37: Well, that was a happy mistake. A rose by any other name ...

WHH@31: Allow me to differ. This blog commentary is a level playing field -- I mean league -- and we are all equals. Your puns are quite good and I have been guilty of more than a few bloopers myself. Please keep the elbows rubbing.

The first time I heard that phrase was at the end of a particularly tryng session of delivered papers at a technical conference that went way over the speaker's alloted time limit. In the mad dash to the men's room afterwards I found myself standing next to an older colleague performing the same function. He turned his head at me and smiled, sayng:" Great minds think alike."
BTW, "SCSI" is pronounced "scuzzy."
And?

John@3: Hic et ubique?

Your comments remind me of John Scarne's highly mathematical book on the theory of gambling (the exact title escapes me but you should be able to find it), where he analyzes in great detail all the odds, strategies and house percentage appropriate to the casino games played in Las Vegas. He was the first to publicize the strategy of counting cards during blackjack, which had two consequences, if memory serves: (1) he became persona non grata at every casino blackjack game there, and (2) in all blackjack games played in those casinos a fresh deck was introduced at random during any run of hands with a given deck (which was discarded), thus voiding the card-following strategy.

I feel like I'm missing something on this problem, and that my solution is probably wrong. It seems to me that the best strategy is to bet everything when there is only one color remaining (obviously), but otherwise bet however much you want on either color because it doesn't matter (counterintuitively).

Using the above strategy, if you start with $S (S=100 in the above problem), and there are n cards with k of them black (and n-k of them red), then I come up with expected final "cash in" value of $S*(2^n)/(nCk), where "nCk" means n!/[k!(n-k)!].

So, for S=$100, n=52, and k=26, you would expect to have at the end of the game ($100)*(2^52)*(26!)(26!)/(52!) =($100)*(2^26)*(26!)/(51!!) =($100)(2^50)/(27*29*31*34*37*41*43*47*49) = ($100)(562949953421312)/(61989816618513) =$908.133 (approx).

So the entry fee should be more than $908.13.

Considering how counterintuitive this answer is, I'll just wait to see if anyone else comes up with something different so that I can see where I might have gone wrong.

The New York times editorials had the crux of the true scandal before today's "apology".  The public hardly needs another dose of cynicism about politicians.  Rep. Wiener never should have married, then his personal life would be no ones business.  But either way, his bald faced lies and obfuscations are the true issue.  He should never be trusted with the responsibilities of serious office.
#60: who asks " who was hurt by Weiner's behavior? and what laws were broken?" Sir, anyone who needs to ask these two questions  would never understand the obvious answers.

Frankly Breitbart based on the largely ridiculous persecutions of Acorn and NPR is a fairly sleazy character willing to go to any means to justify his political ends. As a consequence initially I believed that Weiner was possibly not guilty of the acts(not a crime) although his statements seemed awfully peculiar and possibly knowledgeable of the fact that all evidence could be easily retrieved whether deleted or not. Because of the Breitbart association with Huffington I ignore it.
Regarding Weiner, he's been married a year and if he really loved his wife flirting in any fashion should be out of the question. All that I can say is: mid-life crisis or just really sophomoric? Sad I agree with his views on the country but doing even a 'restrained Favre'?

Liam SFC,

I am not at all implying that the USA should be ranked higher than England.
Having said that, any football fan knows that FIFA's rankings are dubious.

I will say, unequivocally, that England are a consistently overrated side and have been for a long time.

You see there is one thing most American football fans have in common, they do not root for England and more specifically do not fall for the ridiculous hyperbole spewing from across the pond every year.

Carry on, mate. This is highly entertaining.

Cheers

So lets all move to Vermont!!

You can bet the big health care industry will do everything in their power to thwart this. Would also suspect big pharma will not be happy with this and will attempt to jeopardize the move.

Just hope the state's attorney general has enough smarts to ferret out any shady dealings and will expose as well as prosecute these gangs before they can hatch any covert actions.

If you think this is just hyper conspiracy minded individual posting this then you need to read the current health care fix carefully. It is all about the insurance companies and for every benefit we the public achieve the big boys reap massive benefits/profits.

A good strategy for question (3) would be to not bet anything unless you are sure of the outcome (for example, there are two cards of the same color remaining). If you do that, then you can't lose, so it does not matter what the casino taxes, unless they tax more than 100% of your earnings.

Of course, the casino could remedy that problem if they rule that the game must end when the color of the next card is certain. In that case, the casino would break even without a tax (if the solution in my previous post is correct).
What John?

Oh, here is something I might have misunderstood:

Do you pay the "entry fee" and they give you $100 worth of chips; or, do you pay the "entry fee" and then you have to pay an additional $100 to get the chips?

Apple's announcement comes as more and more of us are facing data caps. What Steve described could have us pushing the limits of our plans.

I also wish there were a way to store more than 5 GB on iCloud. I have more than that stored on my iDisk now, and am not relishing the idea of figuring out what to delete.
Any journalist who qualifies Acorn as a "community organizing group" is ignoring the evidence and further serving leftist politics.
I noticed that you didn't mention that Breitbart ran edited and totally doctored videos of ACORN employees' interactions with O'keefe. Give ACORN a break.
I've seen all of Sherrod's comments.  She admits discriminating against whites and says she later changed her ways.  So that erases the fact that she was at first a racist?

Already deaf in one ear from birth, I don't want to lose the hearing in the other. I will certainly stay away from stadiums like this... now if I could only convince motorcyclists that I don't appreciate or am impressed by their loud pipes, I would be equally happy. This one ear is very precious to me.

It is unbelievable that something like this could take place in 2007.  In recent years laws have been established to help to protect the rights of disabled individuals.  But we, as a society need to change our attitude about how we feel about people with disabilities.  If we are not accepting of people who are different, then sadly things like this will continue to happen.
@richard denver: Help me out here. What are the "obvious" answers?

Last fall I encountered a moon jelly while wading at night off a beach in  Connecticut. As I brushed it with my leg it light up bright as a moon - instantly, big as a cantaloupe, it seemed, though probably more like a grapefruit. I nearly jumped out of my skin. No harm done to me, and hopefully not to it either. It would have been nice not to have been so startled and spooked, but all the same it was an experience I feel privileged to have had.

What kind of low-life person takes nude pictures of himself, let alone sends it to a member of the opposite sex???

Weiner needs a good psychiatrist.

Thank you Andrew Brietbart and ABC.
Mr. Jobs isn't going to touch the center of my life, digital or otherwise.
